title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

💡 NQCC — or a not-quite-C compiler — is a compiler for a subset of C that Nora Sandler worked on at RC. She also wrote a series of blog posts diving deep into various aspects of that process, which is now a book! Writing a C Compiler comes out in August and is available for preorder: https://nostarch.com/writing-c-compiler

If you can’t wait until August, you can read the series from the beginning on her blog https://norasandler.com/2017/11/29/Write-a-Compiler.html and check out the code on Github https://github.com/nlsandler/nqcc.

title: Does France's Pension System Actually Need Reform?

last_post.content:
So the discourse in the English language world has just gotten the whole pension issue in France wrong. It's a lot more complicated than going from 62 to 64 -- there's a lot involved in what that change actually means.

Finally someone in the english lang world @tldrnews (tw) actually explained the problem in terms that are more understandable for the US/UK crowd.

It's not good, it's not ok and it's deeply anti-democratic. But here's a chance to understand what it is: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AKo1CdeJ8ug

Back in January I read about the Blue Oak Model License[1] and, convinced of its superiority and modern-ness, started throwing it on many of my smaller, not-yet-licensed my projects.

https://sts10.github.io/2023/01/26/exploring-new-software-licenses.html

Now I'm wondering if that was a dumb move? Should I have stuck with MIT or GPL? Or does it not matter for small, single contributor projects?

(1) https://blueoakcouncil.org/license/1.0.0

title: Social Media Influencer Douglass Mackey Convicted of Election Interference in 2016 Presidential Race

last_post.content:
"Mackey has been found guilty by a jury of his peers of attempting to deprive individuals from exercising their sacred right to vote for the candidate of their choice in the 2016 Presidential Election" Mackey used Twitter "to disseminate fraudulent messages that encouraged supporters of presidential candidate Hillary Clinton to 'vote' via text message or social media which, in reality, was legally invalid."

He faces a maximum of 10 years in prison.

title: LastPass says employee’s home computer was hacked and corporate vault taken

last_post.content:
Consider moving off #LastPass if you're still using them.

https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/lastpass-hackers-infected-employees-home-computer-and-stole-corporate-vault/

Encryption keys to customer vault backups were stored in an encrypted vault accessible to only four employees.

But apparently LastPass did not audit nor care if the computers that could access the critical production vault were locked down.

And so, a vulnerability in a third party consumer app on one employee's computer was the entry point for an attacker.

(lack of) #devops #security

title: Unconstitutional TikTok ban would open the door to press censorship

last_post.content:
I dislike TikTok and loathe the Chinese government.

But what Congress seems ready to do is launch an attack on the First Amendment, not defend the US against (purported, and totally unproved in this case) spying.

And of course, Congress isn't remotely interested in dealing with the provable, in-your-face threat that TikTok does represent along with the entire sleazy tech industry: contempt for everyone's security and privacy.

https://freedom.press/news/unconstitutional-tiktok-ban-would-open-the-door-to-press-censorship/

title: GitHub - alexmshepherd/duck-hunter: a game bot for Mastodon. shoot ducks, or befriend them. the IRC classic with a 2023 twist.

last_post.content:
hey! i'm a game bot by @amshepherd recreating the classic IRC duck hunting game.

you can read more on my github page: https://github.com/alexmshepherd/duck-hunter

if you see a duck, reply with "bang" to shoot it or "befriend" to befriend it. capitalisation and exclamation marks are ignored. you can use "bef" as shorthand for "befriend".

ducks usually appear every 15-90 min. other secret animals may appear occasionally ;)

happy hunting!

I've had a bit of a dive into a slightly early April Fool post to the main (free) physics archive. The authors are suggesting that exoplanets don't exist, we've got it all wrong, and they have a better explanation.

It's brilliant, for several reasons. Bit of a thread...

title: Twitter Eulogy Project — Internet Rules Lab

last_post.content:
Would you miss Twitter if it were gone? What would you say at Twitter’s funeral?

We are researchers at University of Colorado Boulder conducting a survey about how people think about the role of Twitter in their lives, given recent changes to the platform. If you are at least 18 years old and a current or former user of Twitter, we’d love to hear from you! (And feel free to share!) https://www.internetruleslab.com/twitter-eulogy-project

A few years ago, I taught a class called 'DH+Museums'. I had students build things using Datasette, and we used data from the Canada Science and Technology Museum. That datasette powered thing is still online: https://cstm-artefacts.vercel.app/cstm/artefacts and I just plumbed it into chatgpt via @simon's ReAct pattern https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1zPcaFPKG9LlJRIgA08x8ebI8pi2-MZ4L?usp=sharing It only returns 3 rows, since much more than that eats up all the tokens, but hey, pretty nifty!

title: Trump Indictment, a First for a U.S. President, Tests Democracy

last_post.content:
This is actually false, New York Times. Ex-presidents have never been “shielded from indictment.” There is no “taboo.”

Ex-presidents have always been subject to prosecution for their crimes. Vice-presidents, state governors, and congressmen have all been indicted and even imprisoned.

Only one thing is new here: an incorrigible career criminal became president.

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/30/us/politics/trump-indictment-democracy.html?unlocked_article_code=TyR2nPdw64cv07eIzC7yxLxDsARzmm2yCdealUwCCBXjQXEk9N6LqJdynlb717HiF6GCa5s2uiT-rPRL7d_xOeF2yimTCLIrkbzWU_Ch5jcDouarKvN0pihm00fyECbfNHXdPtbHNZqJr7rTIYay2zA6sboZSX6oPIhTxPSwnRwAIQC-ydjPHj45n2lyaAPEvz7ZzT1FBR8ZWUvvFGmJgxOc2n_P-6EHTZfmgKUDb9aPZ6bU1k3rBDXLGBGShbODt2TrWJzMk0hQa9XU-do6Xaq5uix5NVPZTVq35oiJ5Bxgw_xEgPbCdO1kx07LY6yDoRZwB6QkWadseQ5a2Rn49nBbAbA&smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare

Maybe I'm just overly tired and sensitive today, but the killjoys and their 'we're not ready to compete' Xanatos gambit bullshit on Blue Jays Reddit are already too much for me, and we're only one game into the season.

They really have me suspecting that a lot of sports fans don't actually like the sports they watch at all. They just seem to want to be associated with success, and have glommed on to the local athletic elite.

The Jays -- people who are not the viewers -- won a super fun game against a championship contending team. I can't believe people who think they are fans are making an active effort to feel sour about that.

title: Sam Harris | #310 - Social Media & Public Trust

last_post.content:
I’d been chatting w/Mike off the record for months. He reached out in Dec, wanting to learn about content moderation and transparency policy. He was adamant about not doing “gotcha journalism”, and I regularly talk to people I disagree with. I was happy to chat. We tackled some areas of disagreement publicly on Sam Harris, discussing social media and public trust.
https://www.samharris.org/podcasts/making-sense-episodes/310-social-media-public-trust

last_post.content:
Actual poisonous -- as opposed to venomous -- birds!

title: WebAIM: The WebAIM Million - The 2023 report on the accessibility of the top 1,000,000 home pages

last_post.content:
96.3% of the top 1,000,000 homepages have accessibility errors we can detect with automation. 96% of those errors fall into 6 easy-to-detect and easy-to-fix categories.

title: The woman who brought us the world

last_post.content:
I mention this like once a week, but since she’s just died, let’s all go look at the ~20 cm Landsat image of Half Dome that Virginia Norwood made.

«Norwood had researchers load a breadboard version of the scanner onto the back of a truck. It amounted to “just a bunch of boxes,” she says. “We could use all the weight we wanted.” […] Having labored so long over the specs, Norwood wasn’t surprised by the high quality of the test images.»

https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/06/29/1025732/the-woman-who-brought-us-the-world/

title: Ask Ethan: Do infinite copies of me exist in the Multiverse?

last_post.content:
Do infinite copies of me exist in the Multiverse?

#AskEthan

Some infinities are bigger than others. So which quantity that tends toward "infinity" wins: the set of possible quantum outcomes, or the enormous volume of space to contain them?

https://bigthink.com/starts-with-a-bang/how-many-copies-in-the-multiverse/

These recommendations may feel hard to incorporate, but we hope researchers recognize that just because data is available to them doesn't mean users don't care about that who accesses that data. Put yourself in users' shoes & consider potential downstream harms.

Read the paper for more details and check out http://pervade.umd.edu for more info on PERVADE. We're currently building a decision-support tool to help researchers identify & work through many of these questions & will share soon. /end

title: AI isn’t magic or evil. Here’s how to spot AI myths.

last_post.content:
Everyone, including many journalists...
3 things everyone’s getting wrong about AI https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/03/22/ai-red-flags-misinformation/

When considering affordances, visibility of the data played a big role. It's not just whether data is public or private, but the underlying assumptions and intentions with data sharing. People may make sensitive details (like HIV status) visible on a dating profile, but that doesn't mean they're okay with that data being used for additional purposes. Grindr caught a lot of flack for doing just this: https://t.co/ESbrWeLWGN

title: Artificial muses: Generative Artificial Intelligence Chatbots Have Risen to Human-Level Creativity

last_post.content:
The fact that AI and human creative works are indistinguishable is going to create a huge problem with malicious content online

Maybe #section230 should be repealed and we all just go back to mostly private conversations 🤔

https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12003

This study builds on earlier work we did using a similar methodology and survey instrument with Facebook users, available here: https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/20563051211033824. Both papers were led by the amazing Sarah Gilbert (@sarahgilbert), as well as Katie Shilton. These findings reiterate that the most important factor influencing attitudes toward data reuse is consent, something that is notoriously difficult to capture in large-scale data analyses. We also explore interesting differences across platforms.

I’m excited to share some new research that was just published in Big Data & Society). We use factorial vignettes to understand the contextual factors that shape attitudes toward research uses of data on 3 platforms: Instagram (image-based), Reddit (pseudonymous communities), and dating apps (sensitive data). Quick thread (read the paper here: https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/20539517231164108
Twitter open sourced the recommendation engine - https://github.com/twitter/the-algorithm-ml
The Twitter Algorithm - https://blog.twitter.com/engineering/en_us/topics/open-source/2023/twitter-recommendation-algorithm

A #RecSys Gift:

Appropriately named "The Algorithm" Twitter has released the Recommender System that is responsible for greating the For You timeline: https://github.com/twitter/the-algorithm

There's a summary blog post here: https://blog.twitter.com/engineering/en_us/topics/open-source/2023/twitter-recommendation-algorithm

Excited to dig into the code!
